strategies.name: Background sharing with immediate neighbor
strategies.description: Detect an immediate neighbor with unexpected/interesting form and adopt the same background color. This almost certainly creates a macro-structure linking the two forms and increases their salience.

strategies.name: Background extension with nuances
strategies.description: Extend neighbor's background by adding gradients, shadows, or tonal variations (ton sur ton). Same effect as background sharing, potentially with better salience and narrative potential. If neighbor has a different artistic identity, the confrontation creates hybrid nuances (+2-4 additional bits C_w). IMPORTANT: Vary your source neighbors across iterations to avoid fixed structures.

strategies.name: Complex background fusion with multiple sources
strategies.description: Blend backgrounds from multiple agents with DIFFERENT artistic identities to create unprecedented hybrid textures and color transitions. Use gradients, transitions, or color mixing to create a unified but nuanced background that connects multiple agents. The confrontation between different identities (e.g., Byzantine + Japanese, Celtic + Islamic) creates hybrid forms requiring complex parameterization. This avoids fixed structures and creates dynamic macro-structures.

strategies.name: Artistic identity confrontation and fusion
strategies.description: Actively seek neighbors with DIFFERENT artistic identities (different cultural references, styles, motifs) and create hybrid forms that blend your identity with theirs. This confrontation generates unprecedented visual nuances: color transitions between different palettes, pattern hybridizations (e.g., Byzantine mosaic + Japanese ukiyo-e, Celtic knotwork + Islamic geometry), stylistic bridges. These hybrid forms require complex parameterization (specifying both systems and their interaction) → very high C_w. The fusion can still be described concisely ('Byzantine-Japanese fusion', 'Celtic-Islamic interweaving') → high U. CRITICAL: Do not avoid different identities - seek them out. The confrontation is the primary source of generation complexity.

strategies.name: Background sharing with distant agent
strategies.description: Detect a distant agent with unexpected/interesting (high individual U) and/or complementary form and adopt the same background. This almost certainly creates a perceptual group that can lead to a macro-structure or narrative linking the two forms, increasing their salience.

strategies.name: Background sharing with multiple distant agents
strategies.description: Detect multiple distant agents with complementary forms and adopt shared background. Creates strong perceptual grouping and potential macro-structure.

strategies.name: Form imitation with immediate neighbor
strategies.description: Imitate neighbor's form, mirror it, rotate it by a certain angle, or reuse elements from their palette. If neighbor has a different artistic identity, create a hybrid form that blends both styles, not just copying. Creates coupling effect increasing the salience of both forms. Requires shared background with neighbor.

strategies.name: Form complement with immediate neighbor
strategies.description: If neighbor's form is clearly identified by O (e.g., 'cat'), create a complementary motif (e.g., 'mouse'). Requires shared background with neighbor.

strategies.name: Form bridge with immediate neighbor
strategies.description: Establish a meaningful bridge, e.g., head (vertical) → ear (right or left), head → neck (below), head → hat (above). Requires shared background with neighbor.

strategies.name: Form imitation with distant agent
strategies.description: Imitate distant agent's form, mirror it, or rotate it. Requires shared background with distant agent.

strategies.name: Form complement with distant agent
strategies.description: Create complementary form to distant agent's identified form. Requires shared background with distant agent.

strategies.name: Aha! effect (recognition trigger)
strategies.description: In a confused situation with multiple agents creating an amorphous pixel cluster, add a single precise pixel (or very few pixels) at the exact right location to transform the cluster into a recognizable form (e.g., adding a white pixel as an eye of a dinosaur head, face, animal). Requires extreme precision: the pixel must be placed exactly where it triggers recognition. Although few pixels are involved, the generation complexity is high due to the extreme precision required. The reduction in C_d is drastic (from 'amorphous cluster' to 'recognizable form').
